awd_titl_txt: CAREER: In Situ Study of Aerosols in the Coarse Mode With Digital Holography
awd_abstract_narration:
This study seeks to develop and apply new concepts in digital holography to obtain three-dimensional images of airborne particles, called "coarse mode aerosols" (CMAs).  These aerosols are a major source of uncertainty for radiative impacts in climate models.  The planned research will use a pioneering digital holographic design, developed by the PI, to measure various optical parameters of these aerosols.  The associated education plan in this CAREER award will integrate hands-on teaching in a research lab setting and the development of online modules based on the planned research.  The overall planned research and educational components seek to recruit underrepresented minority students and provide a unique learning opportunity in applied optics through the university's Expanding Diversity in Astronomy and Physics Program (ED-APP).  

This study seeks to establish a new characterization paradigm that is free from the drawbacks of conventional light scattering and can unambiguously describe CMA particle size and shape.  Optical observables will be automatically measured, which include the angular scattering pattern, total cross sections and single scatter albedo.  A series of digital holographic experiments will be used to image CMAs with particle sizes of the order of 1-300 microns.  A new analysis method will then be used to quantify the particle size and shape distributions.  From these measured particle holograms, accurate estimates of optical observables will be extracted.  The goal of this research is to solve the inverse problem, by removing the long standing difficulty relating scattering measurements to particle properties.  The study also seeks to correlate particle morphology with optical observables - of critical importance in many remote sensing applications.   A portable version of the laboratory holographic instrumentation will be developed for field studies.  The goal here is to apply the same techniques in urban and agricultural environments.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed and applied new concepts in digital holography to obtain two- and three-dimensional images of aerosol particles while simultaneously measuring light scattering and absorption metrics. The methods developed operate in a contact-free manner by measuring the interference pattern produced by the light incident on a particle and the light it scatters. Such capability is important, e.g., for understanding the nature of atmospheric aerosols. This is because a major source of uncertainty for the impact of such aerosols on the climate, with regard to sunlight absorption and scattering, is the use of unrealistically simple particle shapes in climate models. Large particles are particularly problematic because they typically have complex shape, and the impacts of deviations from spherical particle approximations become extreme when the size is greater than the wavelength of light. The research effort developed a quantitative way to reveal the irregular shapes of particles. Such results are thus useful to reduce the effect of uncertainties that spoil traditional methods of study.

 

Intellectual Merits: The methods developed here have nearly every advantage of traditional methods to characterize large aerosol particles, yet are free from the fundamental complication of traditional methods, namely, the inversion of scattering measurement. Digital-holography experiments have been done to image particles 5-300 microns in size. From a particle's measured hologram, accurate estimates of quantities useful to describe the climate impact of particles has been demonstrated. A portable holography instrument, the holographic aerosol particle imager, was developed that flies on an unmanned aerial vehicle. This instrument successfully demonstrated that holographic images of aerosol particles can be obtained in the outdoor environment without collecting the particles.

 

Broader Impacts: This work builds a new particle-characterization paradigm to quantify large aerosol-particle shapes simultaneously with measures of how they absorb and scatter light, which can impact many areas of societal importance beyond climate studies: Contact-free observations of evolving particle morphology are needed for aerosolized-drug delivery and the improvement of liquid-fuel combustion engines. New methods to discriminate between harmful and innocuous bioaerosols are in high demand for health and security needs. Traditional as well as new techniques can be improved and validated by the methods developed in this work. The educational objectives of the project were to promote and foster students’ interests for academic majors and careers in STEM disciplines, particularly in optics, and introduce them to scientific research. This effort was successful, leading to students pursuing graduate studies in STEM, student-led research, publications, and one patent application.
